name: 2-chloro-5-trifluoromethylpyridine
Reason: The basic unit, pyridine, has a melting point around -42°C. The introduction of a chlorine atom typically raises the melting point due to the increase in polarizability and possible dipole-dipole interactions; this effect can be estimated at +50°C. The trifluoromethyl group also raises the melting point due to its strong electronegativity, which contributes to dipole-dipole interactions, as well as its size increasing the molecular weight; its effect might be estimated at around +25°C.
Test (Predicted reason):
The base structure of the target compound is a pyridine ring, which has a melting point of around 10°C. The presence of a chlorine atom (Cl) and a trifluoromethyl group (CF3) will significantly alter this value. The chlorine atom is a heavy halogen that increases the melting point due to its high electronegativity and the resulting dipole-dipole interactions. This could add approximately 20°C. The trifluoromethyl group is highly electronegative and also increases the melting point due to its size and the potential for dipole-dipole interactions. This could add another 20°C. The cumulative effect of these functional groups on the melting point is the prediction.
